question.title: Does the default constructor get called during object deserialization when using ObjectInputStream?

node.contents: Ways to find it: 1) put a `println/log` in your constructor 2) try to deserialize a class without default constructor.

astNode.text: Ways to find it: 1) put a `println/log` in your constructor 2) try to deserialize a class without default constructor.

node.contents: AFAIK It uses sun.misc.Unsafe.allocateInstance() on OpenJDK/HotSPot.

astNode.text: AFAIK It uses sun.misc.Unsafe.allocateInstance() on OpenJDK/HotSPot.

node.contents: closing my own question (duplicate). Answer is No - it doesnt call default ctor

node.contents: New to Java and I was using browxy to try and answer this question and it doesnt allow creation of files.

astNode.text: New to Java and I was using browxy to try and answer this question and it doesnt allow creation of files.

node.contents: So I was wondering if in the following code, when readObject gets called, does it call the default constructor (if one exists) or not? (also, is there a MemoryStream (C#) equivalent in Java?)

astNode.text: So I was wondering if in the following code, when readObject gets called, does it call the default constructor (if one exists) or not? (also, is there a MemoryStream (C#) equivalent in Java?)

elements.contents: import java.util.*; import java.io.*; public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World"); try { TestClass tc = new TestClass(); FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream("t.tmp"); ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(fos); oos.writeObject(tc); oos.close(); FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("t.tmp"); ObjectInputStream ois = new ObjectInputStream(fis); TestClass tcClone = (TestClass)ois.readObject(); ois.close(); } catch(Exception e) { System.out.println(e); } } } class TestClass implements Serializable { public TestClass() { System.out.println("TestClass CTOR"); } }

units.rawText: import java.util.*; import java.io.*; public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World"); try { TestClass tc = new TestClass(); FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream("t.tmp"); ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(fos); oos.writeObject(tc); oos.close(); FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("t.tmp"); ObjectInputStream ois = new ObjectInputStream(fis); TestClass tcClone = (TestClass)ois.readObject(); ois.close(); } catch(Exception e) { System.out.println(e); } } } class TestClass implements Serializable { public TestClass() { System.out.println("TestClass CTOR"); } }

node.contents: I was wondering if in the following code, when readObject gets called, does it call the default constructor (if one exists) or not?

node.contents: is there a MemoryStream (C#) equivalent in Java?

astNode.text: is there a MemoryStream (C#) equivalent in Java?

node.contents: For classes that implement java.io.Externalizable, the public no-arg constructor is called.

astNode.text: For classes that implement java.io.Externalizable, the public no-arg constructor is called.

node.contents: For other serialisable classes, the accessible no-arg constructor of the most derived non-serialisable base class is called. The serialisable classes' readObject methods are called as if the are constructors (or at least, constructor bodies immediately after returning from calling the super constructor).

astNode.text: For other serialisable classes, the accessible no-arg constructor of the most derived non-serialisable base class is called. The serialisable classes' readObject methods are called as if the are constructors (or at least, constructor bodies immediately after returning from calling the super constructor).

node.contents: It's a common misunderstanding that serialisable classes need a public no-arg constructor. They do not.

astNode.text: It's a common misunderstanding that serialisable classes need a public no-arg constructor. They do not.
